segment.source: We followed these basic steps as we developed the visual aspects of Marble Maze:
segment.target: We followed these basic steps as we developed the visual aspects of Marble Maze:

segment.source: Create a basic framework that initializes the Direct3D and Direct2D environments.
segment.target: Create a basic framework that initializes the Direct3D and Direct2D environments.

segment.source: Use image and model editing programs to design the 2-D and 3-D assets that appear in the game.
segment.target: Use image and model editing programs to design the 2-D and 3-D assets that appear in the game.

segment.source: Ensure that 2-D and 3-D assets properly load and appear in the game.
segment.target: Ensure that 2-D and 3-D assets properly load and appear in the game.

segment.source: Integrate vertex and pixel shaders that enhance the visual quality of the game assets.
segment.target: Integrate vertex and pixel shaders that enhance the visual quality of the game assets.

segment.source: Integrate game logic, such as animation and user input.
segment.target: Integrate game logic, such as animation and user input.

segment.source: We also focused first on adding 3-D assets and then on 2-D assets.
segment.target: We also focused first on adding 3-D assets and then on 2-D assets.

segment.source: For example, we focused on core game logic before we added the menu system and timer.
segment.target: For example, we focused on core game logic before we added the menu system and timer.

segment.source: We also needed to iterate through some of these steps multiple times during the development process.
segment.target: We also needed to iterate through some of these steps multiple times during the development process.

segment.source: For example, as we make changes to the mesh and marble models, we had to also change some of the shader code that supports those models.
segment.target: For example, as we make changes to the mesh and marble models, we had to also change some of the shader code that supports those models.

segment.source: When we planned the Marble Maze Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game, we chose C++ and Direct3D 11.1 because they are the best choices for creating 3-D games that require maximum control over rendering and high performance.
segment.target: When we planned the Marble Maze Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game, we chose C++ and Direct3D 11.1 because they are the best choices for creating 3-D games that require maximum control over rendering and high performance.

segment.source: DirectX 11.1 supports hardware from DirectX 9 to DirectX 11, and therefore can help you reach more customers more efficiently because you don't have to rewrite code for each of the earlier DirectX versions.
segment.target: DirectX 11.1 supports hardware from DirectX 9 to DirectX 11, and therefore can help you reach more customers more efficiently because you don't have to rewrite code for each of the earlier DirectX versions.

segment.source: Marble Maze uses Direct3D 11.1 to render the 3-D game assets, namely the marble and the maze.
segment.target: Marble Maze uses Direct3D 11.1 to render the 3-D game assets, namely the marble and the maze.

segment.source: Marble Maze also uses Direct2D, DirectWrite, and Windows Imaging Component (WIC) to draw the 2-D game assets, such as the menus and the timer.
segment.target: Marble Maze also uses Direct2D, DirectWrite, and Windows Imaging Component (WIC) to draw the 2-D game assets, such as the menus and the timer.

segment.source: Finally, Marble Maze uses XAML to provide an app bar and allows you to add XAML controls.
segment.target: Finally, Marble Maze uses XAML to provide an app bar and allows you to add XAML controls.

segment.source: This class handles general infrastructure, and not game-specific assets.
segment.target: This class handles general infrastructure, and not game-specific assets.

segment.target: During initialization, the DeviceResources::Initialize method creates device-independent resources and the Direct3D and Direct2D devices.

segment.source: The DeviceResources class separates this functionality so that it can more easily respond when the environment changes.

segment.source: The DeviceResources::CreateDeviceResources method calls D3D11CreateDevice to create the device object that represents the Direct3D display adapter.
segment.target: The DeviceResources::CreateDeviceResources method calls D3D11CreateDevice to create the device object that represents the Direct3D display adapter.

segment.source: Because Marble Maze supports feature level 9.1 and above, the DeviceResources::CreateDeviceResources method specifies levels 9.1 through 11.1 in the array of values.

segment.source: Note The term view has a different meaning in the Windows Runtime than it has in Direct3D.
segment.target: Note The term view has a different meaning in the Windows Runtime than it has in Direct3D.

segment.source: In the Windows Runtime, a view refers to the collection of user interface settings for an app, including the display area and the input behaviors, plus the thread it uses for processing.

segment.source: In Direct3D, the term view has multiple meanings.
segment.target: In Direct3D, the term view has multiple meanings.

segment.source: First, a resource view defines the subresources that a resource can access.
segment.target: First, a resource view defines the subresources that a resource can access.

segment.source: For example, when a texture object is associated with a shader resource view, that shader can later access the texture.
segment.target: For example, when a texture object is associated with a shader resource view, that shader can later access the texture.

segment.source: One advantage of a resource view is that you can interpret data in different ways at different stages in the rendering pipeline.
segment.target: One advantage of a resource view is that you can interpret data in different ways at different stages in the rendering pipeline.

segment.source: For more information about resource views, see Texture Views (Direct3D 10).
segment.target: For more information about resource views, see Texture Views (Direct3D 10).

segment.source: When used in the context of a view transform or view transform matrix, view refers to the location and orientation of the camera.
segment.target: When used in the context of a view transform or view transform matrix, view refers to the location and orientation of the camera.

segment.source: A view transform relocates objects in the world around the camera’s position and orientation.
segment.target: A view transform relocates objects in the world around the camera’s position and orientation.

segment.source: For more information about view transforms, see View Transform (Direct3D 9).

segment.source: Marble Maze uses the BasicLoader::LoadShader method to load a shader from a file.
segment.target: Marble Maze uses the BasicLoader::LoadShader method to load a shader from a file.

segment.source: Shaders are the fundamental unit of GPU programming in games today.
segment.target: Shaders are the fundamental unit of GPU programming in games today.

segment.source: Nearly all 3-D graphics processing is driven through shaders, whether it is model transformation and scene lighting, or more complex geometry processing, from character skinning to tessellation.
segment.target: Nearly all 3-D graphics processing is driven through shaders, whether it is model transformation and scene lighting, or more complex geometry processing, from character skinning to tessellation.

segment.source: For more information about the shader programming model, see HLSL.
segment.target: For more information about the shader programming model, see HLSL.

segment.source: Marble Maze uses vertex and pixel shaders.
segment.target: Marble Maze uses vertex and pixel shaders.

segment.source: A vertex shader always operates on one input vertex and produces one vertex as output.
segment.target: A vertex shader always operates on one input vertex and produces one vertex as output.

segment.source: A pixel shader takes numeric values, texture data, interpolated per-vertex values, and other data to produce a pixel color as output.
segment.target: A pixel shader takes numeric values, texture data, interpolated per-vertex values, and other data to produce a pixel color as output.

segment.source: Because a shader transforms one element at a time, graphics hardware that provides multiple shader pipelines can process sets of elements in parallel.
segment.target: Because a shader transforms one element at a time, graphics hardware that provides multiple shader pipelines can process sets of elements in parallel.

segment.source: The number of parallel pipelines that are available to the GPU can be vastly greater than the number that is available to the CPU.
segment.target: The number of parallel pipelines that are available to the GPU can be vastly greater than the number that is available to the CPU.

segment.source: Therefore, even basic shaders can greatly improve throughput.
segment.target: Therefore, even basic shaders can greatly improve throughput.

segment.source: The MarbleMaze::LoadDeferredResources method loads one vertex shader and one pixel shader after it loads the overlay.

segment.source: Presenting the scene
segment.target: Presenting the scene

segment.source: After drawing all 2-D and 3-D scene objects, Marble Maze presents the rendered image to the monitor.
segment.target: After drawing all 2-D and 3-D scene objects, Marble Maze presents the rendered image to the monitor.

segment.source: It synchronizes drawing to the vertical blank to ensure that time is not spent time drawing frames that will never be actually shown on the display.
segment.target: It synchronizes drawing to the vertical blank to ensure that time is not spent time drawing frames that will never be actually shown on the display.

segment.source: Marble Maze also handles device changes when it presents the scene.
segment.target: Marble Maze also handles device changes when it presents the scene.

segment.source: After the MarbleMaze::Render method returns, the game loop calls the MarbleMaze::Present method to send the rendered image to the monitor or display.
